repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fix #1354 

This enables a `@cython.trashcan` directive which can enable using the Python trashcan for deallocations. This is optional, disabled by default (but one could argue about making it enabled by default).

Also see https://bugs.python.org/issue35983

comment_data.body: No need to scream. ;-) Just name it `PyTrashcan` or `PyTrashcanSupport`.

We could increase the minimum version for Cy3.0 *iff* this feature is used, i.e. we can make it fail to compile with a C `#error` right here if `PY_VERSION_HEX < 2.7.4`.
But I'd rather turn the macros into no-ops for older versions. In 99% of the cases, that's still better than not working at all. I mean, you can currently get a crash with Py2.7.3 in rare situations, and you'd get a crash in the future for them. Nothing lost, really.

We should consider using the original macros in Py3.8+ if/when that contains the fixes.
I also wonder if PyPy's `cpyext` supports the trashcan at all, or if this is a CPython-only feature (for now?).
If you use `//` comments here, then they will not appear in the C files.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -74,6 +74,41 @@ static int __Pyx_PyType_Ready(PyTypeObject *t) {
     return r;
 }
 
+/////////////// TRASHCAN.proto ///////////////
+
+// These macros are taken from https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/11841
+// Unlike the Py_TRASHCAN_SAFE_BEGIN/Py_TRASHCAN_SAFE_END macros, they
+// allow dealing correctly with subclasses.
+//
+// This requires Python version >= 2.7.4 or >= 3.2.4
+
+#define __Pyx_TRASHCAN_BEGIN_CONDITION(op, cond) \
+    do { \
+        PyThreadState *_tstate = NULL; \
+        /* If "cond" is false, then _tstate remains NULL and the deallocator \
+         * is run normally without involving the trashcan */ \

comment_data.body: If multiple tests are run without forking, then this one will kill the whole test process on failure. Why not set a flag on the class instead, or use a global counter, or something like that? That would also allow to check that the deallocation was actually executed (ignoring PyPy's GC here).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,62 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cimport cython
+from libc.stdlib cimport abort
+
+
+def recursion_test(f, int n=2**20):
+    x = None
+    cdef int i
+    for i in range(n):
+        x = f(x)
+
+
+@cython.trashcan(True)
+cdef class Recurse:
+    """
+    >>> recursion_test(Recurse)
+    """
+    cdef public attr
+    cdef int deallocated
+
+    def __init__(self, x):
+        self.attr = x
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        # Check that we're not being deallocated twice
+        if self.deallocated:
+            abort()  # Can't raise exceptions here...
+        self.deallocated = 1
+
+
+cdef class RecurseSub(Recurse):
+    """
+    >>> recursion_test(RecurseSub)
+    """
+    cdef int subdeallocated
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        # Check that we're not being deallocated twice
+        if self.subdeallocated:
+            abort()  # Can't raise exceptions here...

comment_data.body: Shouldn't this also depend on `@trashcan(False)`? (And there is no test for that usage.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2085,6 +2085,18 @@ def needs_gc(self):
             return not self.parent_type.is_gc_simple
         return False
 
+    def needs_trashcan(self):
+        # If the type or any of its base types have Python-valued
+        # C attributes, then it should use the trashcan in tp_dealloc.
+        if self.has_cyclic_pyobject_attrs and self.directives.get('trashcan', False):
+            return True
+        base_type = self.parent_type.base_type
+        if base_type and base_type.scope is not None:
+            return base_type.scope.needs_trashcan()
+        elif self.parent_type.is_builtin_type:
+            return not self.parent_type.is_gc_simple

comment_data.body: No need for semicolons after the two macro calls.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1537,6 +1543,10 @@ def generate_dealloc_function(self, scope, code):
             code.putln("(*Py_TYPE(o)->tp_free)(o);")
             if freelist_size:
                 code.putln("}")
+
+        if needs_trashcan:
+            code.putln("__Pyx_TRASHCAN_END;")

comment_data.body:
> If multiple tests are run without forking, then this one will kill the whole test process on failure.

But the Cython testsuite actually deals with that quite nicely. It seems that tests are run in a subprocess.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,62 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cimport cython
+from libc.stdlib cimport abort
+
+

+    x = None

+        x = f(x)

+    def __dealloc__(self):

+            abort()  # Can't raise exceptions here...
+        self.deallocated = 1
+
+
+cdef class RecurseSub(Recurse):
+    """
+    >>> recursion_test(RecurseSub)
+    """
+    cdef int subdeallocated
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        # Check that we're not being deallocated twice
+        if self.subdeallocated:
+            abort()  # Can't raise exceptions here...

comment_data.body:
I took this from the `needs_gc` check and it also makes sense to me. If a base class needs the trashcan, then the subclass really should use the trashcan too. The whole point of the CPython PR is to skip the trashcan for subclasses. But then the trashcan support should be implemented by the subclass.

If you insist, I can of course change this, but I'd rather not.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2085,6 +2085,18 @@ def needs_gc(self):
             return not self.parent_type.is_gc_simple
         return False
 
+    def needs_trashcan(self):
+        # If the type or any of its base types have Python-valued
+        # C attributes, then it should use the trashcan in tp_dealloc.
+        if self.has_cyclic_pyobject_attrs and self.directives.get('trashcan', False):
+            return True
+        base_type = self.parent_type.base_type
+        if base_type and base_type.scope is not None:
+            return base_type.scope.needs_trashcan()
+        elif self.parent_type.is_builtin_type:
+            return not self.parent_type.is_gc_simple

comment_data.body:
> No need to scream. ;-) Just name it `PyTrashcan` or `PyTrashcanSupport`.

I prefer to use `TRASHCAN` in the name because the upstream macros are also called `Py_TRASHCAN_SAFE_BEGIN` and `Py_TRASHCAN_SAFE_END`. It will be more confusing if Cython uses a different made-up name.
I was referring to the name of the utility code snippet, not the C macros (where upper case is normal). There is no precedent for an all-upper-case utility code name.
Except when forking is disabled, e.g. under Windows or with `--debug`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,62 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cimport cython
+from libc.stdlib cimport abort
+
+
+def recursion_test(f, int n=2**20):
+    x = None
+    cdef int i
+    for i in range(n):
+        x = f(x)
+
+
+@cython.trashcan(True)
+cdef class Recurse:
+    """
+    >>> recursion_test(Recurse)
+    """
+    cdef public attr
+    cdef int deallocated
+
+    def __init__(self, x):
+        self.attr = x
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        # Check that we're not being deallocated twice
+        if self.deallocated:
+            abort()  # Can't raise exceptions here...
+        self.deallocated = 1
+
+
+cdef class RecurseSub(Recurse):
+    """
+    >>> recursion_test(RecurseSub)
+    """
+    cdef int subdeallocated
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        # Check that we're not being deallocated twice
+        if self.subdeallocated:
+            abort()  # Can't raise exceptions here...

comment_data.body:
Sounds reasonable, but then we should at least emit a warning when a user writes
```cython
@cython.trashcan(False)
cdef class sublist(list): ...
```
Silently ignoring directives seems unhelpful. You can use `None` as directive default to detect an explicit `False`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

> Silently ignoring directives seems unhelpful. You can use `None` as directive default to detect an explicit `False`.

OK, I'll do this.

comment_data.body: Could this reset the `double_deallocations` counter? Otherwise, if one test fails, all subsequent tests will also fail, and it will be unclear where to look first.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,144 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cimport cython
+
+
+# Count number of times an object was deallocated twice. This should remain 0.
+cdef int double_deallocations = 0
+def assert_no_double_deallocations():
+    assert double_deallocations == 0

commit.message: @cython.trashcan directive to enable the Python trashcan for deallocations

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: @cython.trashcan directive to enable the Python trashcan for deallocations
